column1: By Steve Holland
| JACKSON
column2: Miss.

column1: JACKSON
column2: Miss. Nigel Farage
column3: a key figure in the successful campaign to get Britain out of the European Union
column4: lent his support to Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday
column5: saying Trump represented the same type of anti-establishment movement that he masterminded in his own country.Farage appeared with Trump before a cheering crowd of thousands at a rally in Jackson
column6: Mississippi. Farage partly based his Brexit drive on opposition to mass immigration to Britain that he said was leading to rapid change in his country. His appearance came as Trump sought to moderate his own hardline stance against illegal immigration. In remarks broadcast on Wednesday
column7: Trump backed further away from his vow to deport millions of illegal immigrants
column8: saying he would be willing to work with those who have abided by U.S. laws while living in the country.Trump summoned Farage on stage in the middle of his appearance
column9: shook his hand and surrendered the microphone to him.Farage said he would not actually endorse Trump because he did not want to repeat what he called President Barack Obama's meddling in British affairs when Obama urged Britons to vote to stay in the EU.""I cannot possibly tell you how you should vote in this election. But you know I get it
column10: I get it. I'm hearing you. But I will say this
column11: if I was an American citizen I wouldn't vote for Hillary Clinton if you paid me
column13: I wouldn't vote for Hillary Clinton if she paid me
column14: he added.Trump has sought to align himself with the Brexit movement
column15: noting he had said before the June 23 referendum that Britons should vote to leave. He visited one of his golf courses in Scotland the day after the vote and boasted that he had predicted the outcome and called it a sign his own campaign would be successful.

column1: Trump has since tumbled in national opinion polls and is fighting to remain competitive with Democratic rival Clinton with little more than two months to go until the Nov. 8 election.""November 8 is our chance to redeclare American independence
column2: Trump said
column3: borrowing a phrase Farage used during the Brexit campaign.'FANTASTIC OPPORTUNITY'

column1: Farage drew parallels between the Brexit movement and the support Trump has received from many Americans who feel left behind by Washington.
They feel people aren't standing up for them and they have in many cases given up on the whole electoral process and I think you have a fantastic opportunity here with this campaign
column2: he said.Trump's comments on immigration came in the second part of an interview conducted on Tuesday with Fox News anchor Sean Hannity. They signaled a further softening in his immigration position as he tries to bolster support among moderate voters and minority groups.Trump
column3: who defeated 16 rivals for the Republican presidential nomination in part based on his opposition to illegal immigrants
column4: said he would not permit American citizenship for the undocumented population and would expel lawbreakers.To qualify to remain in the United States
column5: Trump said
column6: illegal immigrants would have to pay back taxes.

column1: No citizenship. Let me go a step further - they'll pay back taxes
column2: they have to pay taxes
column3: there's no amnesty
column4: as such
column5: there's no amnesty
column6: but we work with them
column7: Trump said.""But when I go through and I meet thousands and thousands of people on this subject
column8: and I've had very strong people come up to me ... and they've said: 'Mr. Trump
column10: but to take a person who's been here for 15 or 20 years and throw them and their family out
column13: '"" Trump said. ""It's a very hard thing.""Trump said he would outline his position soon.""Well
column14: I'm going to announce something over the next two weeks
column15: but it's going to be a very firm policy
column17: a CBS affiliate in West Palm Beach
column18: Florida.Trump's new position seemed to resemble in some respects the failed 2007 reform push by former Republican President George W. Bush. That effort offered a way to bring millions ""out of the shadows"" without amnesty and would have required illegal immigrants to pay a fine and take other steps to gain legal status. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-wikileaks-idUSKCN11006B	Assange says WikiLeaks to release 'significant' Clinton campaign data	"

WASHINGTON WikiLeaks founder and editor-in-chief Julian Assange said on Wednesday his organization planned to release ""significant"" information linked to the campaign of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton before the Nov. 8 election.Asked if the data could be a game-changer in the election
column2: the Australian told Fox News in an interview conducted by satellite: ""I think it's significant. You know
column3: it depends on how it catches fire in the public and in the media.""Assange has been living in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London for five years to avoid extradition to Sweden
column4: where he faces sexual assault accusations. He denies the allegations.  WikiLeaks released files in July of what it said were audio recordings pulled from the emails of the Democratic National Committee that were obtained by hacking its servers.

column1: That release
column2: during the Democratic National Convention where Clinton was officially named the party's presidential nominee
column3: was the second batch in a series that deeply rattled the party and prompted the committee's chairwoman
column4: Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column5: to step down.

column1: I don't want to give the game away
column2: but it's a variety of documents
column3: from different types of institutions that are associated with the election campaign
column4: some quite unexpected angles
column5: some quite interesting
column6: some even entertaining
column7: Assange said when asked how the next revelations would compare with those in JulyWikiLeaks publishes leaked material
column8: mostly from governments. In 2010
column9: the organization published classified U.S. military and diplomatic documents in one of the largest information leaks in U.S. history.

column1: (Reporting by Eric Walsh; Editing by Paul Tait)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-climate-law-idUSKCN10Z2SM	California legislature passes climate change bills	"
By Rory Carroll
| SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO California lawmakers voted to extend the state's climate change fighting efforts out to 2030 on Wednesday
column2: giving a new lease on life to the most ambitious greenhouse gas reduction program in the country.The state Senate voted 25-13 in support of a bill that sets a target of cutting the state's output of heat-trapping emissions 40 percent below 1990 levels by 2030. The state is currently on track to meet its 2020 goal of reducing emissions back to 1990 levels. The vote came hours after the state Assembly passed a linked bill to increase legislative oversight of the climate change programs run by the California Air Resources Board by a vote of 44-28.Both bills will now go to Governor Jerry Brown
column3: who has said he will sign them.

column1: Senator Fran Pavley
column2: the author of the 2006 law that set the state's first emission reduction target
column3: said that effort has generated billions of dollars in investment in the state's clean energy sector while creating jobs and reducing emissions. ""Today's action will ensure the state remains on its prosperous and healthy course
column4: she said. At a press conference
column5: Brown said the legislation would impact all industries in the state from oil refining and agriculture to building construction and public utilities.

column1: It's about the world in which we live becoming decarbonized and sustainable
column2: he said. ""These regulations will work to achieve that goal
column3: he said. Opponents said the emissions targets have caused job losses in the communities they represent. ""The impacts in my county are immense
column4: Senate Republican Leader Jean Fuller
column5: who represents Bakersfield
column6: said prior to the vote on Wednesday.

column1: She said the current policies have driven hundreds of energy jobs out of her county
column2: which is home to oil producers and manufacturers. ""The changes it has brought to our economy are unforgiveable
column3: she said.Lawmakers did not address a central threat to the state's carbon cap-and-trade program from the California Chamber of Commerce
column4: which has filed a lawsuit arguing that the state's quarterly carbon permit auctions amount to an illegal tax on businesses.Both climate bills are silent on the question of what policy mechanisms - such as cap and trade - should be used to achieve the 2030 goal. Brown
column5: a staunch supporter of cap and trade
column6: told reporters all options
column7: including a ballot measure in 2018
column8: were on the table to ensure the future of the carbon market. "

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-mylan-idUSKCN10Z2AV	Clinton calls for lower price on allergy drug EpiPen	"
By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton called on pharmaceutical company Mylan NV to voluntarily drop the price of its severe allergy treatment drug EpiPen
column2: which has increased in price by more than 400 percent in the past decade.""That's outrageous - and it's just the latest troubling example of a company taking advantage of its consumers
column3: Clinton said in a statement. ""It's wrong when drug companies put profits ahead of patients
column4: raising prices without justifying the value behind them.""Clinton frequently said during the primary that she would fight pharmaceutical companies - part of an attempt to counter criticism that she was too closely tied to the insurance industry. She has released a proposal that she says will lower drug costs for consumers.Mylan spokeswoman Nina Devlin did not respond to inquiries about Clinton's criticism of the company. Mylan acquired the product in 2007
column5: and the price increased from $100 in 2008 to its current cost of $600.Shares of Mylan closed down more than 5 percent at $43.15 on the Nasdaq.""The price of EpiPen is outrageous
column6: said Robert Weissman
column7: president of consumer watchdog group Public Citizen. ""Mylan is endangering lives and ripping off the country.""Weissman said EpiPen's U.S. price should be rolled back sharply
column8: noting the product is available for as little as $112 in Canada. Many other drugmakers also routinely raise prices of their prescription drugs by 10 percent or more each year
column9: and U.S. legislation is needed to prevent such ""price spikes

column1: The White House took a more cautious tone in criticizing rising drug costs
column2: refusing to comment on the decisions of an individual company. ""I will observe
column3: however
column4: that pharmaceutical companies that often try to portray themselves as the inventors of life-saving medication often do real damage to their reputation by being greedy and jacking up prices in a way that victimizes
column5: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said at a news briefing.    Clinton joins a bipartisan group of lawmakers who are calling for investigations into the price increase of EpiPens
column6: which are preloaded injections of epinephrine (adrenaline) that people use if they are having a dangerous allergic reaction that untreated could result in death. Republican Senator Chuck Grassley
column7: chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee
column8: wrote Mylan earlier in the week to ask for an explanation of the price change. Senator Amy Klobuchar
column9: the top Democrat on the committee's antitrust subcommittee
column10: called for an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Republican Senator Susan Collins and Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill requested that Mylan provide a briefing for the Senate to explain the price change.Grassley and Klobuchar
column3: along with Democratic Senators Patrick Leahy and Richard Blumenthal and Republican Senator Ron Johnson
column4: on Wednesday said they had written to the Food and Drug Administration to ask about its approval process for alternatives to the EpiPen.""Given the importance of this topic
column5: it is imperative to understand the FDA's role with respect to EpiPens and its approval of generic equivalents that could help to increase competition and lower prices if introduced
column6: the senators said in a statement.  ""We have reached out to every member of Congress who has sent us a letter
column7: and we look forward to meeting with them and responding to their questions as soon as possible
column8: Devlin said.

column1: In January
column2: Clinton admonished Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc
column3: which raised the price of a heart drug. In the wake of a Clinton campaign blog post targeting Valeant
column4: the company's stock fell. In March
column5: she released a campaign ad vowing to target the company specifically. Clinton also criticized Turing Pharmaceuticals in the fall of 2015 when public ire rose after it decided to raise the price of an antiviral medication commonly used by AIDS patients and pregnant women from $13.50 a tablet to $750 each. After a single post by Clinton on the social media website Twitter critical of Turing
column6: the company's stock price tumbled. At that time
column7: Clinton released a comprehensive drug price plan that she says would reduce costs. Her proposal includes capping monthly out-of-pocket costs
column8: expanding generic drug access and allowing Americans to buy pharmaceuticals abroad. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has said little about lowering drug prices. He has proposed increasing the amount of negotiations permitted by Medicare in order to lower prices for those using the program. (Additional reporting by Ransdell Pierson; Editing by Bernard Orr and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-adviser-idUSKCN10Z2OX	Trump adviser's Russia credentials come under scrutiny	"
By Alexander Winning and Olga Popova
| MOSCOW
MOSCOW When Donald Trump named a little-known U.S. energy consultant as part of his foreign policy team
column2: the adviser's ex-boss was puzzled; how could the relatively junior banker he knew in Moscow a decade ago be qualified to brief a presidential candidate?Carter Page
column3: who worked in Russia at U.S. investment bank Merrill Lynch
column4: paints an impressive picture of his three-year stint from 2004
column5: saying on his company's website that he advised on ""key"" transactions involving some of the country's biggest energy groups.But Sergey Aleksashenko
column6: who became head of the bank's Moscow operation toward the end of Page's assignment
column7: expressed  doubts about whether he has the experience to act as an adviser on Washington's fraught ties with the Kremlin.""For me it was a strange choice
column8: said Aleksashenko
column9: who served as a deputy finance minister and deputy central bank governor in the 1990s before running Merrill Russia in 2006-2008. ""Carter was never a person who would discuss foreign policy or U.S.-Russian relations."" The achievements of Page - whom Trump named as an adviser in March - are summarized on the website of New York-based Global Energy Capital LLC
column10: a firm that he founded after leaving Merrill. He did not respond to Reuters questions about his time in Russia and Merrill Lynch declined comment.When contacted by Reuters
column11: Trump's spokeswoman Hope Hicks played down Page's role in the campaign. ""Mr. Page is an informal adviser named as part of a much larger group several months ago. He does not speak for or represent the campaign in any official capacity
column13: who is now the Republican nominee
column14: named Page as being among five foreign policy advisers in an interview with The Washington Post on March 21. Hicks did not answer Reuters questions seeking to clarify what Page had done since then for the campaign and why Trump had picked him.    Aleksashenko
column16: was Page's boss in 2006-07 and is now a nonresident senior fellow at the left-leaning Brookings Institution in Washington.  Three other former Merrill employees in Moscow also told Reuters that Page could not have played a leading role in the bank's deals due to his rank
column17: and at the time showed no real interest or expertise in foreign policy.Shortly after Trump named his foreign affairs team
column18: campaign member Sam Clovis said the aim was to recruit people with ""real-world"" and military experience rather than the retreads that other candidates relied on.""These are people who work for a living
column19: the New York Times quoted Clovis as saying. ""If you're looking for show ponies
column20: you're coming to the wrong stable.""Clovis was not immediately available for further comment.FLATTERING COVERAGE

column1: Russia has been a central issue in the U.S. election campaign
column2: with Trump calling President Vladimir Putin a ""strong leader"". Flattering coverage of Trump in Russian state media has left little doubt that he would be the Kremlin's preferred candidate over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.Like Trump
column3: Page holds views that contradict the Obama administration's stance on Russia and in recent years he has expressed them
column4: reflecting the Kremlin's views on occasions.In a February 2015 article in the journal Global Policy
column5: he said U.S. policy toward Russia had been ""misguided and provocative"" and blamed the State Department for precipitating the Ukraine conflict.In a speech given in Moscow last month
column6: Page also criticized Western countries for what he said was their ""hypocritical focus on democratization"" in the post-Soviet world. At the event
column7: he did not respond to questions about his time in Russia.Andrey Kortunov
column8: director general of the Russian International Affairs Council
column9: said Trump wanted to show the incompetence and weakness of the foreign policy pursued by the Democrats. Page was useful as his views fit with that aim
column11: who does not know the Trump adviser personally.""There are people in the U.S. who are bored with Ukraine
column12: who think it is not an American problem that Washington should be involved in
column14: whose think tank is close to the Russian Foreign Ministry but who has also expressed independent views. Despite Hicks's comments
column15: Trump's former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski told Reuters that when he left the campaign in late June
column16: Page had ""definitely"" been an adviser to Trump.

column1: Another member of the five-strong foreign policy team
column2: Walid Phares
column3: told Reuters on Aug. 19 that Page continued to advise Trump.A MID-TIER BANKER

column1: The Global Energy Capital LLC website says Page was responsible for opening Merrill's Moscow office and that he was ""an advisor on key transactions"" for Russian firms including Gazprom
column2: the world's top gas producer
column3: and RAO UES
column4: a power company that no longer exists.Reuters spoke to four former Merrill employees in Moscow
column5: three of whom overlapped with Page
column6: as well as three Moscow-based bankers who competed with the U.S. bank for business. With the exception of Aleksashenko
column7: none agreed to speak on the record about their recollections which differ from Page's.""Page was a vice president at Merrill
column8: a mid-tier banker who was not originating deals
column9: said Aleksashenko. ""Gazprom was a VIP client and in no transaction with such a client could a vice president play a decisive role.""

column1: In an interview with Bloomberg in March
column2: Page said he advised Gazprom on the purchase of a stake in the Sakhalin energy project in Russia's Far East from Shell.Aleksashenko said Merrill's contribution to that deal was merely to provide a straightforward document saying the transaction was at fair value to Gazprom shareholders
column3: alongside other banks.Gazprom declined comment.Another ex-Merrill banker said: ""Page was a general dogsbody who would have sat in on most meetings and prepared documents.""A third ex-Merrill banker
column4: whose comments were corroborated by Aleksashenko
column5: said Merrill's business with Gazprom when Page worked there involved investor relations work.Page also said he worked on deals in central Asia. Two sources who were involved in the initial public offering of shares in Kazakh firm KazMunaiGas EP in 2006 said although Merrill was one of the IPO's managers
column6: they did not remember Page participating in the deal.CLOSER TO THE COMPANY

column1: Bankers at rivals when Page worked in Moscow said Merrill was not the main bank Gazprom turned to when it needed to raise capital
column2: although the U.S. bank handled its investor relations. Merrill did act as a manager on two Gazprom Eurobonds when Page worked in Moscow but Tom Adshead at Moscow-based consultancy Macro-Advisory
column3: which helps foreign investors in Russia
column4: said it was not a major player with the energy group.""There are other bankers who were viewed in the market as being closer to the company
column5: said Adshead
column6: who worked in Moscow as an analyst and was a fund manager at the time that Page was at Merrill.Merrill Lynch declined to respond to Reuters questions on Page's work with the bank in Moscow.  (Additional reporting by Mark Hosenball in WASHINGTON
column7: Oksana Kobzeva and Olesya Astakhova in MOSCOW
column8: Olzhas Auyezov and Mariya Gordeyeva in ALMATY; Editing by Andrew Osborn and David Stamp)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-exclusive-idUSKCN10Z2MO	Exclusive: Clinton leads Trump in key swing states
column2: would likely win election - poll	"

column1: By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK If the U.S. presidential election were held today
column2: Democrat Hillary Clinton would win the key swing states of Florida
column3: Ohio and Virginia and have a 95 percent chance of beating Republican Donald Trump to become America's first female president
column4: according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project.The project
column5: which combines opinion polls with an analysis of voting patterns under different election scenarios
column6: shows Clinton currently beating Trump in the popular vote by six percentage points and ahead in 19 states
column7: including most of the larger-population ones that heavily influence the outcome of the election.At the moment
column8: Clinton would win at least 268 votes in the Electoral College
column9: the body that ultimately chooses the next president
column10: just two shy of what she needs to win the White House. On average
column11: the former secretary of state would win by 108 electoral college votes.Trump would win at least 21 states
column12: many of them with smaller populations
column13: giving him a minimum of 179 electoral votes.The election is still 10 weeks away
column14: and a great deal could change prior to Nov 8. The candidates are running about even in eight states
column17: and the polling sample is too small to determine the winner in Alaska
column18: Wyoming and Washington D.C. But Trump would need to win the 21 states currently in his column and sweep all of the remaining ""toss-up"" states to win the presidency.That is a steep challenge for Trump
column20: anti-establishment campaign helped him win the Republican Party's nomination but has so far failed to build broad support with voters.If Trump cannot draw in far greater numbers of women
column22: he will almost surely lose the White House race
column25: what would be an ideal scenario for Trump: white men with below-average incomes showing up in record numbers on Election Day. This group strongly favors the real-estate mogul
column26: yet even if all of them vote it wouldn't hand Trump any of the states currently slated for Clinton or any of the toss-up states. Clinton would still win the election.

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project is driven by an online survey that gathers responses from about 16
column2: 000 people per week. Respondents answer questions about their demographic background
column3: their party affiliation and their choice for president. Their responses are weighted according to the latest population estimates
column4: and each respondent is ranked according to their likelihood to vote.Once the poll is complete
column5: the project tallies the levels of support and estimated error for both candidates
column6: and then runs multiple election simulations given their respective support. A separate set of simulations is run for each state and Washington D.C. The project runs more than 25 million simulations to determine the chances that one candidate would win.

column1: Click on the image above for the project's interactive tool that allows users to set turnout targets for various voter groups.
Representatives from the Clinton and Trump campaigns did not respond to requests for comment on the project. OCTOBER SURPRISE?
A polarizing candidate
column2: Trump has called for a more extensive border wall with Mexico
column3: a ban on Muslim immigrants and a rejection of international trade agreements. His personal attacks
column4: including his criticism of the parents of a Muslim-American soldier killed in action
column5: have undermined his support within the Republican establishment.Still
column6: Clinton is far from guaranteed a victory in November.A majority of Americans have an unfavorable opinion of both Trump and Clinton
column7: and nearly one out of four likely voters says they do not support either of them for president
column8: according to a separate Reuters/Ipsos poll.The candidates are scheduled to square off in a series of televised debates
column9: and a poor showing by either could quickly change the dynamic of the race. A strong showing by a third party candidate could also influence the outcome.

column1: Democratic Party operatives also fear there may be more revelations about ties between wealthy foreign donors to the Clinton family charity
column2: the Clinton Foundation
column3: and the State Department under her stewardship. Clinton has denied any impropriety but Trump has seized on the disclosures as a new line of attack against his rival.""There's always a chance of an October surprise - something definitive and striking about Clinton - that could change the race
column4: said Tom Smith
column5: who directs the Center for the Study of Politics and Society at the University of Chicago. ""But
column6: short of any scandals by the Clintons
column7: I just don't see any way that Trump catches up.""If Trump were to rely heavily on support from white voters
column8: he would face an extremely narrow path to victory. Even if all male and female white voters showed up at the polls
column9: and turnout among blacks and Hispanics was half of what it was in 2012
column11: the project shows Clinton would still be favored to win.It appears that Trump's best chance is to turn out Republican voters in huge numbers and hope that a lot of Democrats stay home.There's only one problem with this: Republicans appear to have turned out as strongly as Democrats only once in presidential elections since at least 1976. That was in 2004
column12: when the electorate was made up of 37 percent of Republicans
column13: 37 percent of Democrats and 26 percent of Independents
column14: according to exit poll data collected by the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research at Cornell University.""There's still a lot of this demolition derby of an election to go
column16: a political scientist at Columbia University. ""A lot of people who support Trump don't have a very good record of voter turnout
column17: and who knows if they show up this time. (Editing by Paul Thomasch

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN10Z03R	Trump suggests potential softening in hardline position on immigration	"
By Steve Holland
| AUSTIN
column2: Texas

column1: AUSTIN
column2: Texas U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump held out the possibility on Tuesday of a softening of his hardline position on illegal immigration
column3: a move that could help move him to the political center but hurt him with his most ardent supporters.In an immigration town hall event with Fox News anchor Sean Hannity
column4: Trump was asked whether he would be willing to change U.S. law to accommodate those illegal immigrants who have been contributing to American society
column5: obeyed laws and have children.""There certainly can be a softening because we're not looking to hurt people
column6: Trump replied
column7: insisting there were some ""great people"" among the immigrant population.It was the latest example of Trump appearing to waver on his long-held stance he would deport all illegal immigrants back to their home countries. His new campaign manager
column8: Kellyanne Conway
column9: told CNN on Sunday that Trump's proposed ""deportation force"" for the 11 million people in the United States illegally was ""to be determined.""Later on Tuesday
column11: Trump appeared to shift his emphasis to dealing with illegal immigrants who commit crimes in the United States. He brought on stage eight mothers whose children were killed by illegal immigrants.Trump ticked off a series of statistics about crimes committed by some illegal immigrants and vowed that would be stopped under his presidency.""Not going to happen
column13: he said. ""We're not going to let it happen to our country.""Trump
column14: who postponed an immigration speech originally planned for Thursday in Denver
column15: said he would stop some major cities' practice of providing sanctuary for illegal immigrants and stop immigrants from overstaying their visas.

column1: A move by Trump to modify his stance on immigration could help him attract more support among moderate voters in his uphill drive to win the Nov. 8 election.The latest Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Democrat Hillary Clinton expanding her lead over Trump to 12 points among likely voters
column2: with 45 percent support to 33 percent for Trump.But a change in Trump's position could prove to be dispiriting to some of his strongest supporters. Trump defeated 16 rivals for the Republican presidential nomination and one factor that helped him was being the most hardline candidate on immigration. ""Why would anyone be surprised that Trump has pivoted to becoming the 'amnesty' candidate?"" said Republican strategist Rick Tyler
column3: a former spokesman for U.S. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column4: a conservative. ""When you have no governing philosophy
column5: pivots are par for the course. Guess we won't need Mexico to build that wall.""

column1: 'FOLLOW THE LAWS'
At his Austin event
column2: attended by thousands who packed a rodeo arena
column3: some were shouting: ""Build the wall"" long before Trump even showed up
column4: a reference to the New York businessman's oft-stated promise to build a wall along the U.S. with Mexico and make Mexico pay for it.Some of those attending the event
column5: however
column6: liked that Trump might be offering a more expansive view on immigration.""I think he's saying the law needs to be looked at
column7: said Barbara Thomas
column8: a Trump supporter from the Austin area. ""I think it would be very hard for all of them to be deported. I think the system needs to be fixed. It has some problems.""

column1: Immigration politics have long divided American voters. Then-President George W. Bush
column2: a Republican
column3: fought for changes to U.S. immigration laws in 2007 but the effort fizzled in the U.S. Congress. Democratic President Barack Obama's attempts have failed to bear fruit amid partisan gridlock.Trump insisted in the Hannity appearance he would ""follow the law.""""We have very strong laws in this country. And you know Bush
column4: and even Obama
column5: sends people back. Now
column6: we can be more aggressive on that but we want to follow the laws
column7: he said.His vice presidential running mate
column8: Indiana Governor Mike  Pence
column9: said in a CBS News interview that Trump would be ""tough but fair"" in dealing with illegal immigrants.""People who have run afoul of the law gotta leave immediately
column11: he said the details would need to be worked out with Congress. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-farage-idUSKCN10Z2I9	Brexit campaigner Farage says to address Trump rally	"
LONDON Nigel Farage
column2: an anti-immigration politician who was a figurehead of the successful campaign to get Britain out of the European Union
column3: intends to address a Donald Trump rally on Wednesday
column4: a spokesman said.Once dismissed by then-prime minister David Cameron as the leader of a party mostly consisting of ""fruitcakes
column5: loonies and closet racists""

column1: There was no immediate confirmation from the Trump campaign.

Farage's future is unclear. He stepped down as head of the UK Independence Party  (UKIP) after the referendum delivered what he said was the main ambition of his 25-year political career - Britain leaving the EU.Often seen as an abrasive and controversial figure

column3: purple.

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-briefing-idUSKCN10Z2DD	Hillary Clinton to receive intelligence briefing Saturday: sources	"
By Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton is scheduled to receive a pre-election briefing from U.S. intelligence officials on Saturday
column2: a source familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.	Clinton
column3: a former secretary of state
column4: will receive the briefing
column5: an overview of foreign policy and international security issues facing the United States
column6: from career officials in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI)
column7: the source said. CNN reported that the briefing would be given to Clinton at the Federal Bureau of Investigation's field office in White Plains
column8: New York
column11: residence she shares with her husband

column1: Representatives for relevant government agencies and Clinton's presidential campaign had no immediate comment.ODNI officials gave Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump his first intelligence briefing last week at the FBI's Manhattan office. A source said that because Trump asked for his briefing to be broken up into more than one session
column2: he is expected to meet again with intelligence briefers.

column1: Questions have been raised about the extent to which either candidate should be trusted with national security secrets
column2: given the controversies surrounding the private email server Clinton used for State Department business and Trump's penchant for spontaneous comments and tweets.

column1: Sources familiar with the content of the briefings said that while they contain information classified at the Top Secret level
column2: they do not contain information about undercover espionage operations or U.S. intelligence sources and methods. (Reporting By Mark Hosenball in Washington; Editing by John Walcott and Jonathan Oatis)"
